article.title: From the international space station to the clinic: how prolonged unloading may disrupt lumbar spine stability
article.abstract: Prolonged microgravity exposure is associated with localized low back pain and an elevated risk of post-flight disc herniation.

sections.introduction: On Earth, the lumbar spine bears the load of the upper body in upright posture and is stabilized by both passive and active systems [1].
sections.methods: With institutional research board approval, spine imaging and health data were assessed from six NASA astronaut crewmembers at two time points: before launch (“pre”) and 1 day following 6 months’ spaceflight on the ISS (“post”).
sections.results: Following spaceflight, lumbar lordosis decreased (flattened) in all six subjects (average change: −11.1%, p=.009; Table).
sections.discussion: This unique longitudinal study underscores the coupled role of passive and active spine stabilizers in maintaining lumbar spine health.

article.insights_summary: Prolonged microgravity exposure is associated with localized low back pain and an elevated risk of post-flight disc herniation. The study found that 6 months of spaceflight produced significant effects on lumbar biomechanics, including a decrease in lumbar lordosis and intersegmental ROM.
